question: Does JMJD6 hydroxylate the C-terminal lysine 382 of p53 as an α-ketoglutarate- and Fe(II)-dependent lysyl hydroxylase and thereby suppress p53 transcriptional activity? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: We demonstrated that JMJD6 acts as an α-ketoglutarate- and Fe(II)-dependent lysyl hydroxylase to catalyze p53 hydroxylation.
content.source_2: Comprehensive in vivo proteomics failed to detect hydroxylation at the C terminus of p53; instead, the only reproducible site mapped to lysine 120 within the DNA-binding core, excluding K382 as a target.
content.source_3: Depletion of JMJD6 diminished p53 transcriptional output, accelerated S-phase entry, reduced apoptosis, and conferred resistance to DNA-damaging agents, consistent with JMJD6 acting as a transcriptional coactivator of p53.
